text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Woman politician Suliat Adedeji killed in Ibadan, southwestern Nigeria; shot dead by suspected assassins.
- Federal government insists local council elections should be held in December as scheduled, releases 410 million naira to electoral commission to conduct the poll.
- Under new policy private Nigerian investors can now borrow directly from Abidjan-based African Development Bank.
- National carrier Nigeria Airways retrenches 250 staff.
- OPEC secretary general Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria tells seminar in Lagos that OPEC would lose cumulatively $425 billion if developed countries go ahead to impose proposed energy tax.
- Nigeria will not take loans from either World Bank or International Monetary Fund in its economic recovery drive, says chairman of national economic intelligence committee Sam Aluko.
- Central Bank acquires another distressed bank, Victory Merchant Bank, for one naira to restructure and sell.
- Bomb blast at Lagos airport, three feared dead.
- Petroleum Trust Fund to spend 7.4 billion naira on national security.
